questions.question_text:
A database is running in archivelog mode. You want to back up a 10 TB data file belonging to the users tablespace. The backup of the data file is too slow.
What type of backup do you recommend to improve the performance of the backup?

comments.content: Yes, running in parallel mode is the way to go.
True, but image copie is slower afaik. Also there is no unused block compression

discussion.content:
C but B also looks ok

RMAN enables you to create multisection backups using image copies. Multisection backups provide better performance by using multiple channels to back up large files in parallel. Starting with Oracle Database 12c Release 1 (12.1), you can create multisection full backups that are stored as image copies. While the image copy is being created, multiple channels are used to write files sections. However, the output of this operation is one copy for each data file

choices.D: cold backup after taking the tablespace offline
choices.E: cold backup after placing the tablespace in backup mode
choices.A: image copy backup by using RMAN
choices.B: multisection image copy backup by using RMAN
choices.C: multisection parallel backup by using RMAN

discussion.content: yes A B E. took me a while to confirmed this. i had to re-read my books

questions.question_text:
Automatic Undo Management is enabled for your database. You want a user to retrieve metadata and historical data for a given transaction or for transactions in a given time interval.
Which three are prerequisites to fulfill this requirement?

choices.E: The select any transaction privilege must be granted to the user.
choices.B: The database must be running in archivelog mode.
choices.F: The recycle bin parameter must be set to on.
choices.A: Minimal supplemental logging must be enabled.
choices.C: Flashback Data Archive must be created and the flashback archive administer system privilege must be granted to the user.
choices.D: The flashback any table privilege must be granted to the user.

choices.A: expdp will fail because no path has been defined for the dumpfile.
choices.C: inpdp will create two users called hr1 and oe1 and import all objects to the new schemas.
choices.D: impdp will create two users called hr1 and oe1 and import only the tables owned by hr and oe schemas to ht1 and oe1 schemas, respectively.
choices.B: expdp will succeed but impdp will fail because the users do not exist.

discussion.content: D is correct. why would impdp fail ? No reason.

comments.content: In impdp command,value of parameter schemas is 'hr1,oe1', which is not exists in source database. So B is correct.

questions.question_text:
Examine these Data Pump commands to export and import objects from and to the same database.
The dba has not yet created users hr1 and oe1.
$expdp system/manager
schemas = hr.oe
directory = EXP_DIR
dumpfile = export.dat
include = table
$ impdpsysten/manager
schemas = hr1,oe1
directory = EXP_DIR
dumpfile = export.dat
remap_schena=hr:hrl, oe:oe1
What will happen when running these commands?

comments.content: I tested it - its AC - The Tablespace specifications are things like force logging and extent management. Thought AD aswell but its false

discussion.content: I tested it - its AC - The Tablespace specifications are things like force logging and extent management. Thought AD aswell but its false
I would choose for answer AD; With regards to C, what tablespace specifications?

questions.question_text:
Examine the command to create a pluggable database (PDB):
SQL> CREATE PLUGGABLE DATABASE pdb2 FROM pdb1
FILE_NAME-_CONVERT = ('/disk1/oracle/pdb1/', '/disk2/oracle/pdb2/) PATH_PREFIX = '/disk2/oracle/pdb2';
Which two statements are true?

choices.A: The pluggable database pdb2 is created by cloning pdb1 and is in mount state.
choices.B: Details about the metadata describing pdb2 are stored in an XML file in the '/disk2/oracle/pdb2/' directory.
choices.C: The tablespace specifications of pdb2 are the same as pdb1.
choices.E: pdb2 is created with its own private undo and temp tablespaces.
choices.D: All database objects belonging to common users in PD3I are cloned in PD32.

choices.F: tracking the most recent write time for a table segment in the sysauxtablespace
choices.E: tracking the most recent read time for a table segment in the sysauxtablespace
choices.D: tracking the most recent write time for each block in a table segment
choices.B: tracking the most recent write time for a table segment in a user tablespace
choices.A: tracking the most recent read time for a table segment in a user tablespace
choices.C: tracking insert time by row for table rows

questions.question_text: Which three tasks can be automatically performed by the Automatic Data Optimization feature of Information Lifecycle Management (ILM)?
